title: 105_s1787
content: AUTHORIZATION FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE. The United States Customs Service is authorized to receive funding for border investigative resources, anti-corruption efforts, drug smuggling and money-laundering operations, cargo processing, and reducing traffic waiting times. Specific amounts are allocated for fiscal years 1999 and 2000, with additional funding as needed in subsequent years. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for acquiring narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funding for Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, and contraband detection kits. For fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for various technology acquisitions along the Southwest border, including contraband detection kits, ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, and remote watch surveillance camera systems. Funding for technology acquisitions along the Southwest border in fiscal year 1999 includes weigh-in-motion sensors, AM radio stations, inbound vehicle counters, spotter camera systems, inbound commercial truck transponders, narcotics detectors, and more to enhance border security. In fiscal year 2000 and beyond, funds are allocated for maintenance and support of border security equipment, including license plate reader software and detectors at border crossings. The Commissioner of Customs has the authority to use funds for equipment other than specified in subsection (b). In subsection (b), technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost can be obtained. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds for equipment specified in subsection (b). Additionally, funds under subsection (a) can be used for peak hours and investigative resource enhancement. The authorized amounts for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 are $112,844,584 and $180,910,928 respectively. This funding is designated for increasing inspectors and special agents at the Southwest and Northern borders, enhancing investigative resources, deploying canine enforcement officers at cargo facilities, and allocating resources to offices overseeing major metropolitan drug activities. The curr_chunk discusses the allocation of resources for intensifying efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, increasing positions in the Office of Internal Affairs for anticorruption efforts, and covering costs related to personnel increase.
